Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} = iAz \\), where A is a constant real number that dictates the rate of rotation in the complex plane. We explore the effects of the transformation defined by the function \\( f(z) = e^{-At}z \\) over time t.

Knowing only the endpoint \\(z(T)\\), can we determine precisely which transformations were applied (whether \\(f(z)\\), \\(g(z)\\), or both)?
Explanation: Given that both \\(f(z)\\) and \\(g(z)\\) are phase rotations in the complex plane, the endpoint \\(z(T)\\) alone, without knowing the specific dynamics (including time of application and rates A and B), cannot conclusively tell us which transformations were applied. This is due to the overlapping effects of complex rotations that may yield similar endpoints from different transformation sequences.
